prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:

The situation involves a friend of the author who has five children by different fathers and is currently single. The friend has been making comments that the author feels are insulting, especially regarding her single status and the author's own dating life. The author finally responds by pointing out the friend's situation as the reason she can't find someone. The friend is upset, and mutual friends are now criticizing the author for being privileged and not understanding.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The friend's comments are clearly personal attacks, and the author has been trying to brush them off. The final response from the author was honest but direct, possibly hurtful. The friend's reaction was to get angry and hang up. The mutual friends are now taking the friend's side, suggesting the author is privileged.

The key points are: the author was defending themselves from insults, but their response may have been perceived as judgmental or rude. Even though the friend is in a problematic situation, calling out her circumstances might have crossed a line. The author's intention was to stop the insults, but the method might have been unkind.

Also, the author's work in the adult industry might be sensitive, and the friend's past attempts to enter the same field could add to the tension. The author might have felt justified due to the ongoing harassment, but the response could have been more empathetic. The mutual friends' reactions indicate that the author's statement was hurtful, even if they were telling the truth.

So, is the author in the wrong? The answer might depend on whether the response was a necessary truth or an unkind attack. Even if the friend was at fault for the insults, the author's response might have been too harsh. There could have been a better way to set boundaries without being so direct. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong (Answer A) because their response was hurtful, even if they were protecting themselves from abuse.
